name: ModernSuperism
description: I've played a Supermodernism deck for a while now, and I thought I'd try my hand at putting my own spin on it. I have no clue if it'll be any good, but I think it's got potential. I'm gonna test it out over the next couple weeks, see if it's worth a shot.

name: Noise Siphon Pressure
description:
Drawing inspiration from Steven Wooley, I wanted to bump this over to Noise. I think gorman can add a lot of econ to the picture, given the siphoning, and you can recur it with deja vu if the corp is so poor its not worth siphoning.

You get the added bonus of easy mills, so I dropped some of the DLR in favor or more viruses. Hemorrhage should make HQ multi-access not necessary. I think this should be pretty comparable to Reina.

name: Arrested Development V0.2
description: The aim of the deck is to try and keep the runner low on programs so you can score agendas. The Midseason usually scares the runner into wasting time and money for multiple turns, or I use it to get off a Scorched Earth. I added GRNDL Refinery for some bluff and money, and an extra Shipment from Kaguya to help advance stuff.

Bullet to the Face

name: HB 1.0
description: my first corpo deck. Feel free to comment, i'll take every critic

name: Second prize is a set of steak knives
HB - First Deckbuild
description: Welcome any comments

name: Rielle's Hardware Kit
description:
This deck is a work in progress; I expect to be tweaking it for a while to come yet...

I've been looking to get a deck based on Replicator going for a while now. It seems like a card with some very powerful potential, but I struggled to make it click. I had previous decks with Kate and Chaos Theory, but they struggled to apply pressure reliably in the early game. Also, I felt that I was putting in some bits of hardware to help Replicator get more use, rather than because they would help me win the game.

Enter Kit. She doesn't have the inbuilt advantages of Kate or CT, or even the same amount of influence, but she does have her 'Make-a-Gate' ability. All you need is a decoder and you can crack any single ice server. And on the hardware front, you are guaranteed to get use out of Lockpick.

BREAKDOWN:

PROGRAMS: I haven't played with this deck enough to be fully confident in my choices here. Zu.13 is perfect, with its efficiency and cost of one, as an early game breaker. Torch is meant as a late game play, where its higher STR gets it through most code gates trivially. However, Cyber-Cypher has the same strength, and costs 7 less, although it obviously loses flexibility. I'm sticking with Torch for the moment, as it helps more when you need to crack a big remote.

I dislike both sentry breakers, but since I dislike almost all available killers, they'll have to do. Snowball will do, since I don't have the influence for Corroders. Omega is slightly too pricey for my liking, but being able to crack any 2-deep server with just two breakers is pretty brutal, and puts a lot of pressure on the corp.

EVENTS: Money, card draw, and an Escher to mess things up if the corp puts up some effective defences.

RESOURCES: Money and card draw, with an Escher to ruin their defensive setup. I was back and forth on Armitage vs daily casts, but I prefer the burst potential of Armitage, and the cheaper install cost. Inside man does a lot of work in this deck mid-late game, but doesn't always arrive at the right time.

HARDWARE: Cyberfeeder and Lockpick are recurring credits, as is the Spinal Modem. I might drop the latter to free up some influence, but I am happy with it so far. Plascrete is a necessary evil. RDI to help digging. Replicator to help get multiples of all of these out. It also helps thin the deck.

HOW TO USE IT: I struggled a lot in the initial games with it because I was looking for the Replicator to click before I did anything. This worked okay with CT and Kate, but with Kit you lose the early pressure advantage of her ability. So now, I'll mulligan if I do not get a Zu.13 or SMC or Torch. Get a decoder down, and start hassling. Kit works best making one run a turn, use the events and clicks to get a full hand again. If you can get the replicator train rolling, brilliant, but don't sacrifice tempo for it. If your opponent can only lightly ice his servers, go for blood. Don't wait for the replicators; the hardware is in the deck to be stand-alone useful, you'll get more advantage of playing them when needed as opposed to waiting for the combo.

Any comments would be appreciated!

name: Psionic Tag Punishment (Scorcha' Killa' V2)
description:
Through further testing I found the hnters didn't get much done so I traded them in for Tsurugis.

Losing a scorched earth did hurt but I found closed accounts easier to pull off with decent effect and it combos nicely with MRF econ and can turn the deck into something much more taxing though less deadly

name: The Motivated clone
Kate'n Friends
Tenma lean forward Deck
Tennin's Trick
description: Tehshi-chan maji kawaiiyo!

name: ModernSuperism (Restructured)
description:
I've played a Supermodernism deck for a while now, and I thought I'd try my hand at putting my own spin on it. I have no clue if it'll be any good, but I think it's got potential. I'm gonna test it out over the next couple weeks, see if it's worth a shot.

Swapped the 2x Power Shutdowns for a pair of Restructures.

name: Ice Wide Shut
description:
Iterating on my previous corp deck.

  • Changed from Custom Biotics to Stronger Together, because the ICE bonus does seem more useful than simply having more influence

  • ...due to the lower influence, replaced most out-of-faction ICE with cheaper alternatives (eg. Hadrian's Wall became Wall of Thorns). Also replaced Data Ravens with Matrix Analyzers, because I could use free advancement tokens more than a few random tags that aren't leading to anything.

  • Replaced some of my in-faction/neutral ICE with more expensive alternatives.

  • Fewer Assets, more Operations (because I don't think I can rely on having so many remote servers)

  • Replaced low-scoring agendas with Priority Requisitions, to bring down the number of Agendas in the deck (less chance of random theft)... and let me rez Janus for free ;)

Biggest issue I have with it right now is that all my ICE feels really expensive. I think I'm focusing too much on the mid-late game, and just assuming I'll get my defences up. I think I need a small shift in balance towards cheap ICE I can lay down in the first few turns. Also, a nagging feeling that I still don't have enough credit economy.

name: 99 Programs (But Snitch Ain't One)
description:
Iterating on my previous runner deck - currently evolving into a run-of-the-mill Kit/Yog affair.

  • Changed from Mac to Kit, to try messing with people more.

  • Reduced the range of cards in the deck, and increased their number where possible (this includes adding the second Toolbox I bothered to buy, which I now want to swap out for Dinosaurus - sigh...)

  • Added Plascrete Carapace, just in case

  • Added Levy AR Lab Access, although I feel like I should have more "draw" cards to burn through my deck faster - it would help me get my rig set up faster, and give me more economy Events throughout the game

Biggest changes still in mind: Switching to Dinosaurus to give Yog a boost, removing at least one of my standard icebreakers (Battering Ram, Gordian Blade, Pipeline), adding Omega, maybe some Datasuckers, dropping Tinkering for Paintbrush, dabbling with Run events and viruses??

name: New Corp Deck
Just Pay Shipping and Handling V1.2
description:
Born from the idea "can you have too much taxation?" Stick your servers behind as many cheap to rez ICE as possible and watch your opponents credits dwindle away. Pup and Pop-up Window consistently make them pay, while Burke Bugs can let you force them into paying or dealing with serious consequences. Other ICE similarly hold them out early and make them pay later. RSVP can be used to turn a Pop-up Window into a ETR ICE if they aren't being careful.

I originally built this with *TWIY, but the more I played it the more I realized that the extra card was only so helpful, and someone pointed out just how much better Making News could make Burke Bugs and TMI, and now Draco. So I shifted up five cards and this is the result. Let me know what you think

name: Custom Biotics: Express Shipping
Trick of Ice 1.1
Aggressive Dino Lover 1.4
description:
General Idea

I've always been an agressive player, running alot and keeping as much pressure as humanly possible. This deck is custom built for that type of playstyle. Run early, run alot. Have the corp in it's toes, and eventually build up your rig and start digging.

The Cards

Many cards speak for themselves, but I will focus on some of the core mechanics and their cards.

Account Siphon and Indexing

These are the best cards to get early, I almost always keep my hand if I find both in my starting hand. Both cards puts high pressure on the corp. I usually start with a run on HQ, if rez, I index R&D, if the other way around, I Siphon their accounts. Some rush decks will stop both, centrals, but then you know early what kind of deck you are up against. A rule of thumb is to always Account Siphon on your second click, so you can remove the tags.

Self-modifying Code and Clone Chip

This combo has seen many plays before, so I am certain you are familiar with the tactic. Face check with SMC so that you can pull out any breaker you want (keep yourself over 5 credits, preferably around 10). Deus Ex gets rid of all the ice that hurts you (net and brain damage) and Sharpshooter prevents your precious programs from getting trashed.

Ice Breakers

Corroder is an auto include, not much to say there. Zu.13 is just really cheap and easy to pull with SMC. Femme Fatale is a real pain in the ass to hard install (paying full price), but her bypass have always paid out. My theory is that Overmind will be insanely good as early aggression with CT, break those first end the ices and they'll wish they had more subroutines. Use Clone Chip to retrieve SMC (mid-run even) or any of your ice-breakers.

Strategy

Run on your first click, if you get beaten up fine, nothing can kill you in the first turn. If you run into a neural katana, just jack out and draw some cards. As the game progresses, use the standard rule of thumb: Remotes -> HQ -> R&D -> Archives. But if you can, pressure the centrals with Siphon and Indexing. This locks down R&D (that is what this deck does best) and keeping the corp poor (and you filthy rich).

Good luck and have fun!

name: Arrested Development V0.3
description: Switched out the Corporate Wars for 2 Project Atlas' as per GPWK's suggestion.
My version of a Midseason/Psychographics/Beale deck. We'll see how it goes.

name: Reina's Icecapades
description: Rook with Reina's ability and Xanadu is amazing. That's four extra credits to rez the first piece of ice each turn. I've used the Anarch's set breakers to get datasuckers in, to convince the corp to ice up archives, which you also run into. Forcing them to rez or trash ice with FAO and derezzing ICE to force the corp to rez it again feels brilliant.

name: Bleedout (FINAL)
description: What do you say about that deck ? please rate this

name: Chaotic Mind
HB Brain Barbeque v1.0 (Creation & Control)
description:
This deck is designed to flatline the runner, plain and simple.

This is my first Corp deck, so suggestions are very welcome. What expansion cards suit an aggressive play style?

Will start playing with Jinteki and see where I get with an agressive play style, I just like HB as a faction. :)

name: Virulent Shaper v2.0 (C&C)
description:
Using Viruses to make the Core Shaper deck more aggressive.

This deck is now expanded with the Creation & Control set. Mixing out some of the hardware and events from the Core Set to accommodate for more Anarch cards and cheaper Shaper icebreakers like Inti and Atman.

name: Double Tap
description:
My most successful deck. Won 2 local tournaments.

The goal is to get filthy rich and then flatline the runner using Punitive Counterstrike. On top of that it can be, and often is, played normally by just scoring agendas.

It's very easy to get up to 50 creds. If you're rich and have 2 Punitives (or 1 and Archived Memories/Vitruvius counter) in your hand, you can start scoring agendas in the open. Taking them would mean a flatline.

Jacksons recycle agendas if you're not yet ready for the kill, but they can also pull off a neat little trick. If you have only 1 Punitive or the runner has a ton of meat damage protection, stash 2 or more agendas in the archives and put Jackson in a protected server. When Jackson is protected, the runner usually goes for the archives to get rid of him. When he runs the archives, you can decide how many points you're gonna let him have, giving you flexibility for the kill. So if you can, let him have 6.

Paired with a Corporate Troubleshooter or an unsuspecting runner, Shinobi can also flatline. Having a gazillion credits makes this a viable strategy. You'll need this many credits to flatline the runner:

3x(runner's creds + link + bad pub) + 4 + Troubleshooter creds

Most of the time you only need to run the last 2 subs. Even better if you put some ice in front of Shinobi, because every cred the runner spends on breaking is worth 2-3 to you.

Power Grid Overload and Flare are there for Plascrete.

Another good thing about the deck is that the strategy doesn't interfere with normal play. There's enough money and ice to slow advance the agendas. Corporate Troubleshooter plays a part here as well, as you can use heaps of money to pump a Wall of Static to +30 if need be to score a 3 pointer.

name: HB Big ICE
description: Amass credits, set up a scoring server whilst locking them out of whatever server they run the most. Then score whilst safe.

name: 3 point med
Agenda Starvation
description:
The basic idea of this deck is that there are only 6 agendas, meaning that there is only a 15% chance of pulling an agenda out of RnD. It uses extremely taxing ice like Pup, and Eli 1.0, and Snowflake to punish the runner from repeated runs on HQ and RnD. To actually score the agendas, it relies on scoring out a quick Priority Requisition in order to free rez either Tollbooth or Susanoo-No-Mikoto to lock down remote servers. IF THE RUNNER HITS ONE Shi.Kyū, they will then have to score 2 more agendas to make up for it. The math of this deck is insane, and I currently hold a 11 - 3 record with it.

Any criticism welcome!

name: Grappling Queen (beta)
description:
This deck's off to being tested tomorrow against members of my local league.

It's all just pretty straightforward taxing Reina shenanigans with a central mechanic around an awesome breaker suite full of synergy.

e3 Feedback Implants is the real star of the show because it combos with Knight, Grappling Hook and Overmind with ease.

Sheherazade made it's comeback because Grappling Hooks and Crescentus are meant to be trashed soon upon arrival anyways and will work with 14 programs.

The rest is just your typical parasite recursion with the option to RnD lock with medium.

name: Nisei - Death and Taxes
description:
The goal of this deck is to make running too expensive for the runner to pay for taxing agendas.

All of the taxing ice can make running and stealing from remotes very difficult, especially when working in tandem with Caprice.

The bidding mechanic will always net you money if it doesn't end the run, because if you spend the same amount as the runner, you are always spending one less. This means you can just generate income bidding on 0, or you can tax the runner heavily bidding on 2, as you are never spending as much as they are. The econ in the deck can be phenomenal, too, making bidding on 2 very easy.
